title: Finding the Facts: The Creation of Law: An Analysis of the Market, the Constitution and the Law
description: Finding the Facts: The Creation of Law: An analysis of the Market, the Constitution and the Law (20215). 1 or 2 units. In industrialized counties, law is perceived (whether or not applied in fact) as an instrument used to control the activities of the corporate bureaucracies that dominate the economy; and in constitutional societies the instrument is seen as defining limits on public activities. This course will use corporate and constitutional cases to develop the argument that political science and history are a more useful context for the analysis of the United States law than the rationality of economics, but that science cannot deal with whether or not law can be created that is both effective and likely to be obeyed. An introductory corporate law course is a prerequisite; a securities law course would be helpful, but is not required. J.G. Deutsch.
resources: COURSE EVALUATIONS
